facts.title: The Bible Has 66 Books
facts.description: 39 books in the Old Testament and 27 in the New Testament. It was written by approximately 40 different authors over 1,500 years.
facts.didYouKnow: The word 'Bible' comes from the Greek word 'biblia,' meaning 'books.'

facts.title: 31,102 Verses Total
facts.description: The Bible contains 31,102 verses, 1,189 chapters, and approximately 783,137 words in the original languages.
facts.didYouKnow: The middle verse of the Bible is Psalm 118:8.

facts.title: Longest Book: Psalms
facts.description: Psalms is the longest book with 150 chapters and 2,461 verses. The shortest book is 3 John with only 14 verses.
facts.didYouKnow: The longest chapter is Psalm 119 with 176 verses.

facts.title: Most Mentioned Name
facts.description: David is the most mentioned person in the Bible, with over 1,000 references. Jesus is mentioned approximately 973 times.
facts.didYouKnow: The name 'David' means 'beloved' in Hebrew.

facts.title: Dead Sea Scrolls Discovery
facts.description: In 1947, a Bedouin shepherd discovered ancient biblical manuscripts in caves near the Dead Sea, dating back to 200 BC.
facts.didYouKnow: The scrolls included complete books of Isaiah and many other Old Testament texts.

facts.title: Oldest Bible Manuscript
facts.description: The oldest known Bible manuscript fragments date back to around 125 AD, containing portions of the Gospel of John.
facts.didYouKnow: This is the Rylands Library Papyrus P52, kept in Manchester, England.

facts.title: Gutenberg Bible - First Printed
facts.description: In 1455, Johannes Gutenberg printed the first Bible using movable type, revolutionizing Bible distribution.
facts.didYouKnow: Only 49 Gutenberg Bibles still exist today, worth millions of dollars.

facts.title: Bible Timeline Span
facts.description: The events in the Bible span approximately 4,000 years, from Creation to the establishment of the early church.
facts.didYouKnow: The Old Testament covers about 3,500 years of history.

facts.title: Methuselah - Oldest Person
facts.description: Methuselah lived 969 years, making him the oldest person recorded in the Bible (Genesis 5:27).
facts.didYouKnow: His name means 'when he dies, judgment will come.' He died the year of the flood.

facts.title: Shortest Man: Zacchaeus
facts.description: Zacchaeus, a chief tax collector, climbed a sycamore tree to see Jesus because he was too short to see over the crowd.
facts.didYouKnow: Jesus visited his house, transforming his life completely (Luke 19).

facts.title: Jerusalem Mentioned 811 Times
facts.description: Jerusalem is the most frequently mentioned city in the Bible, appearing 811 times. Damascus is second with 60 mentions.
facts.didYouKnow: Jerusalem is considered holy by three major religions: Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

facts.title: Women Authors Debated
facts.description: While most biblical books were written by men, some scholars suggest portions may have been written or influenced by women like Deborah.
facts.didYouKnow: The Song of Deborah (Judges 5) is one of the oldest passages in the Bible.

facts.title: Three Original Languages
facts.description: The Bible was originally written in Hebrew, Aramaic, and Greek. Most of the Old Testament is in Hebrew.
facts.didYouKnow: Jesus likely spoke Aramaic in his daily life.

facts.title: Most Translated Book
facts.description: The Bible has been translated into over 3,500 languages, making it the most translated book in history.
facts.didYouKnow: About 90% of the world can read the Bible in their native language.

facts.title: King James Version Impact
facts.description: The King James Version (1611) shaped English literature and introduced phrases like 'fight the good fight' and 'eat, drink, and be merry.'
facts.didYouKnow: The KJV took 7 years and 47 scholars to translate.

facts.title: No Word for 'Eternity'
facts.description: The Hebrew language in the Old Testament has no single word for 'eternity.' Instead, it uses 'olam,' meaning 'forever' or 'age.'
facts.didYouKnow: This shows how ancient Hebrews conceptualized time differently.

facts.title: 300+ Prophecies About Jesus
facts.description: Over 300 Old Testament prophecies were fulfilled in Jesus Christ, including his birthplace, manner of death, and resurrection.
facts.didYouKnow: The probability of one person fulfilling just 48 prophecies is 1 in 10^157.

facts.title: Isaiah Written 700 Years Before
facts.description: Isaiah 53 describes the suffering servant (Jesus) in remarkable detail, written 700 years before Christ was born.
facts.didYouKnow: Dead Sea Scrolls confirmed Isaiah was written before Jesus lived.

facts.title: Bethlehem Prophecy
facts.description: Micah 5:2 predicted the Messiah would be born in Bethlehem, written 700 years before Jesus birth.
facts.didYouKnow: Bethlehem means 'house of bread' in Hebrew.

facts.title: Crucifixion Details Predicted
facts.description: Psalm 22 describes crucifixion details (pierced hands/feet, divided garments) before crucifixion was even invented.
facts.didYouKnow: Crucifixion was invented by the Persians around 500 BC.

facts.title: 37 Miracles of Jesus
facts.description: The Gospels record 37 specific miracles performed by Jesus, though John says there were many more not recorded.
facts.didYouKnow: John 21:25 says 'the world could not contain the books' if all Jesus did was written.

facts.title: Parting of the Red Sea
facts.description: Moses parted the Red Sea, allowing the Israelites to escape Egypt. Some scholars estimate 2-3 million people crossed.
facts.didYouKnow: This is one of the most dramatic miracles in the Old Testament.

facts.title: Walls of Jericho
facts.description: The walls of Jericho fell after the Israelites marched around the city for 7 days and shouted (Joshua 6).
facts.didYouKnow: Archaeological evidence shows Jericho walls collapsed outward, matching the biblical account.

facts.title: Sun Stood Still
facts.description: Joshua commanded the sun to stand still during battle, and it did for about a full day (Joshua 10:13).
facts.didYouKnow: This allowed Israel to completely defeat their enemies.

facts.title: Shortest Verse
facts.description: 'Jesus wept' (John 11:35) is the shortest verse in the Bible - only two words in English.
facts.didYouKnow: This verse shows Jesus humanity and compassion at Lazarus death.

facts.title: Letter Without 'E'
facts.description: In some ancient manuscripts, the letter 'E' is carefully avoided in certain passages as a literary technique.
facts.didYouKnow: This technique is called 'lipogrammatic writing.'

facts.title: Animals Talk
facts.description: Only two animals speak in the Bible: the serpent in Eden (Genesis 3) and Balaam's donkey (Numbers 22).
facts.didYouKnow: Both times, the animals spoke to deliver God's message.

facts.title: Perfect Palindrome Chapter
facts.description: Psalm 117 is the shortest chapter (2 verses) and sits at the exact center of the Bible.
facts.didYouKnow: It has 594 chapters before it and 594 chapters after it.

facts.title: No Vowels Originally
facts.description: The original Hebrew text had no vowels or punctuation - they were added centuries later by the Masoretes.
facts.didYouKnow: Readers relied on context and tradition to pronounce words correctly.

facts.title: Bible Reading Marathon
facts.description: If read continuously, it would take about 70 hours to read the entire Bible aloud.
facts.didYouKnow: That's about 3 days of non-stop reading.

facts.title: Bestselling Book Ever
facts.description: The Bible is the bestselling book of all time, with over 5 billion copies distributed throughout history.
facts.didYouKnow: An estimated 100 million Bibles are sold or given away each year.

facts.title: Paul Wrote 13 Books
facts.description: The Apostle Paul wrote 13 books of the New Testament, more than any other single author.
facts.didYouKnow: Some scholars debate whether Paul wrote Hebrews, which would make it 14.

facts.title: Moses Wrote 5 Books
facts.description: Moses wrote the first five books of the Bible (Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, Deuteronomy), called the Torah or Pentateuch.
facts.didYouKnow: These books form the foundation of Jewish law and Christian understanding.

facts.title: Only Two Chapters Without Sin
facts.description: The first two chapters of Genesis and the last two of Revelation are the only chapters without any mention of sin.
facts.didYouKnow: These chapters describe paradise before the fall and after restoration.

facts.title: Enoch Never Died
facts.description: Enoch walked with God and was taken to heaven without experiencing death at age 365 (Genesis 5:24).
facts.didYouKnow: Only Enoch and Elijah were taken to heaven without dying.

facts.title: Elijah's Fiery Departure
facts.description: Elijah was taken to heaven in a whirlwind with chariots and horses of fire (2 Kings 2:11).
facts.didYouKnow: Elisha witnessed this and received a double portion of Elijah's spirit.

facts.title: Job's Suffering Timeline
facts.description: Job lost everything in a single day but remained faithful to God, eventually receiving double what he lost.
facts.didYouKnow: Job is considered one of the oldest books in the Bible.

facts.title: Samson's Superhuman Strength
facts.description: Samson killed 1,000 Philistines with a donkey's jawbone and later brought down an entire temple.
facts.didYouKnow: His strength came from his uncut hair as part of his Nazarite vow.

facts.title: David and Goliath
facts.description: Goliath was over 9 feet tall, and David defeated him with just a sling and one stone.
facts.didYouKnow: David chose 5 smooth stones because Goliath had 4 brothers.

facts.title: Noah's Ark Dimensions
facts.description: The ark was 450 feet long, 75 feet wide, and 45 feet high - about the size of 1.5 football fields.
facts.didYouKnow: Naval engineers confirm these dimensions create a very stable vessel.

facts.title: Oldest Church Building
facts.description: The Dura-Europos church in Syria, dating to 233 AD, is the oldest known Christian church building.
facts.didYouKnow: It was discovered in 1920s and contains early Christian frescoes.

facts.title: Codex Sinaiticus Discovery
facts.description: One of the most important biblical manuscripts was discovered at St. Catherine's Monastery in 1844.
facts.didYouKnow: It contains the oldest complete New Testament in existence.

facts.title: Bible Smuggling History
facts.description: During communist rule, Bibles were smuggled behind the Iron Curtain in creative ways, including false car parts.
facts.didYouKnow: Brother Andrew became famous for smuggling Bibles across borders.

facts.title: William Tyndale's Sacrifice
facts.description: William Tyndale was executed in 1536 for translating the Bible into English.
facts.didYouKnow: His last words were 'Lord, open the King of England's eyes.'

facts.title: Feeding 5,000
facts.description: Jesus fed 5,000 men (plus women and children, possibly 15,000 total) with just 5 loaves and 2 fish.
facts.didYouKnow: There were 12 baskets of leftovers, one for each disciple.

facts.title: Walking on Water
facts.description: Jesus walked on water during a storm, and Peter briefly walked on water too before doubting.
facts.didYouKnow: This miracle demonstrated Jesus' authority over nature itself.

facts.title: Lazarus Raised After 4 Days
facts.description: Jesus raised Lazarus from the dead after he had been in the tomb for four days.
facts.didYouKnow: This was one of Jesus' greatest miracles before his own resurrection.

facts.title: Jesus Calms the Storm
facts.description: Jesus rebuked a fierce storm with just the words 'Peace, be still' and immediately there was calm.
facts.didYouKnow: The disciples asked 'Who is this that even wind and waves obey him?'

facts.title: Water Turned to Wine
facts.description: Jesus' first recorded miracle was turning water into wine at a wedding in Cana (John 2).
facts.didYouKnow: He turned approximately 120-180 gallons of water into wine.

facts.title: Virgin Birth Foretold
facts.description: Isaiah 7:14 prophesied a virgin would conceive, written 700 years before Jesus' birth.
facts.didYouKnow: This prophecy was considered impossible until its fulfillment.

facts.title: 30 Silver Pieces Predicted
facts.description: Zechariah 11:12-13 predicted the Messiah would be betrayed for 30 pieces of silver centuries before Judas.
facts.didYouKnow: Even the detail about the money being thrown in the temple was foretold.

facts.title: Not a Bone Broken
facts.description: Psalm 34:20 predicted none of the Messiah's bones would be broken during crucifixion.
facts.didYouKnow: Roman soldiers broke the legs of the criminals beside Jesus but not his.

facts.title: Resurrection Foretold
facts.description: Psalm 16:10 prophesied God would not let his Holy One see decay, predicting the resurrection.
facts.didYouKnow: Peter quoted this psalm on the day of Pentecost.

facts.title: Wycliffe Bible Translators
facts.description: Founded in 1942, Wycliffe has helped translate the Bible into over 700 languages.
facts.didYouKnow: About 2,000 languages still need Bible translation begun.

facts.title: Greek Koine Language
facts.description: The New Testament was written in Koine Greek, the common language of the Eastern Mediterranean.
facts.didYouKnow: This made it accessible to the widest possible audience at the time.

facts.title: Aramaic Sections
facts.description: Parts of Daniel and Ezra were written in Aramaic, the language Jesus spoke daily.
facts.didYouKnow: Some of Jesus' words are recorded in Aramaic, like 'Talitha koum.'

facts.title: Septuagint Translation
facts.description: The Septuagint is the Greek translation of Hebrew Scriptures, created around 250 BC by 70 scholars.
facts.didYouKnow: Jesus and apostles often quoted from the Septuagint.

facts.title: Esther Never Mentions God
facts.description: The book of Esther never explicitly mentions God's name, yet his providence is evident throughout.
facts.didYouKnow: Despite this, it's one of the most powerful books about God's sovereignty.

facts.title: Song of Songs Romance
facts.description: Song of Solomon celebrates romantic love between a husband and wife with beautiful poetry.
facts.didYouKnow: It's also understood as an allegory of Christ's love for the church.

facts.title: Seven Days of Creation
facts.description: Genesis 1 describes creation occurring over six days, with God resting on the seventh.
facts.didYouKnow: This established the seven-day week pattern still used worldwide.

facts.title: Ten Commandments
facts.description: God gave Moses the Ten Commandments on Mount Sinai, written by God's own finger on stone tablets.
facts.didYouKnow: Moses broke the first set in anger and God made a second set.

facts.title: Twelve Tribes of Israel
facts.description: Jacob's twelve sons became the twelve tribes of Israel, though the listings vary slightly.
facts.didYouKnow: Joseph's two sons often replace him, keeping the count at twelve.

facts.title: 40 Days and 40 Nights
facts.description: The number 40 appears frequently: rain during flood, Moses on mountain, Jesus' temptation, etc.
facts.didYouKnow: 40 often represents a period of testing or judgment in the Bible.

facts.title: 7 - Number of Completion
facts.description: The number 7 appears over 700 times in the Bible, symbolizing completion or perfection.
facts.didYouKnow: There are 7 days of creation, 7 churches in Revelation, 7 seals, 7 trumpets.

facts.title: 12 - Number of Government
facts.description: 12 tribes, 12 apostles, 12 gates of heaven - representing God's government or authority.
facts.didYouKnow: New Jerusalem has 12 foundations with the names of 12 apostles.

facts.title: 3 - Number of Divine Completeness
facts.description: Trinity (Father, Son, Spirit), Jesus' 3-day resurrection, Peter's 3 denials.
facts.didYouKnow: Jesus asked Peter 'Do you love me?' three times to restore him.

facts.title: Abraham's Age at Isaac's Birth
facts.description: Abraham was 100 years old when Isaac was born, and Sarah was 90.
facts.didYouKnow: Sarah laughed when God promised her a son at her age.

facts.title: Moses' 120 Year Life
facts.description: Moses lived exactly 120 years - 40 years in Egypt, 40 in Midian, 40 leading Israel.
facts.didYouKnow: His eyes were not weak and his strength not gone when he died.

facts.title: Joseph's Dreams Came True
facts.description: Joseph's dreams of his brothers bowing to him came true when he became Egypt's second-in-command.
facts.didYouKnow: He went from slave to ruler in one day after interpreting Pharaoh's dreams.

facts.title: Daniel in Lions' Den
facts.description: Daniel was thrown into a lions' den for praying to God, but God shut the lions' mouths.
facts.didYouKnow: His accusers were thrown in next and immediately devoured.

facts.title: Jonah and the Great Fish
facts.description: Jonah was swallowed by a great fish for 3 days after running from God's call.
facts.didYouKnow: Jesus referenced Jonah as a sign of his own 3-day resurrection.

facts.title: Ruth's Loyalty
facts.description: Ruth chose to stay with her mother-in-law Naomi, becoming an ancestor of King David and Jesus.
facts.didYouKnow: She's one of only 5 women mentioned in Jesus' genealogy.

facts.title: Esther Saved Her People
facts.description: Queen Esther risked her life to save the Jewish people from genocide in Persia.
facts.didYouKnow: The Jewish festival of Purim celebrates this deliverance.

facts.title: Mary Magdalene First Witness
facts.description: Mary Magdalene was the first person to see Jesus after his resurrection.
facts.didYouKnow: In that culture, women's testimony wasn't accepted in court.

facts.title: Peter's Restoration
facts.description: After denying Jesus 3 times, Peter was restored when Jesus asked him 3 times 'Do you love me?'
facts.didYouKnow: Peter became the bold spokesman at Pentecost, leading 3,000 to Christ.

facts.title: Early Church Persecution
facts.description: The early church faced severe persecution, yet grew from 120 to millions within 300 years.
facts.didYouKnow: The blood of the martyrs became the seed of the church.

facts.title: Council of Nicaea
facts.description: The Council of Nicaea in 325 AD affirmed the doctrine of the Trinity and produced the Nicene Creed.
facts.didYouKnow: Emperor Constantine called this first ecumenical council.

facts.title: Destruction of the Temple
facts.description: The Jerusalem Temple was destroyed by Romans in 70 AD, just as Jesus predicted.
facts.didYouKnow: Not one stone was left on another, exactly as Jesus foretold.

facts.title: Biblical Archaeology Confirms
facts.description: Archaeological discoveries have consistently confirmed biblical accounts, including the Pool of Siloam and Pontius Pilate's existence.
facts.didYouKnow: Over 25,000 sites show correlation with the Bible.

facts.title: Ten Plagues of Egypt
facts.description: God sent ten plagues on Egypt to convince Pharaoh to free the Israelites.
facts.didYouKnow: Each plague was a judgment on a specific Egyptian god.

facts.title: Manna From Heaven
facts.description: God provided bread from heaven (manna) for Israel in the wilderness for 40 years.
facts.didYouKnow: The manna tasted like wafers made with honey.

facts.title: Water From the Rock
facts.description: Moses struck a rock and water gushed out to provide for millions of Israelites.
facts.didYouKnow: Paul says this rock was Christ, providing spiritual water.

facts.title: Fiery Furnace Survival
facts.description: Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego survived a fiery furnace so hot it killed the guards.
facts.didYouKnow: A fourth person appeared with them in the fire, like 'a son of the gods.'

facts.title: Widow's Oil Multiplied
facts.description: Elisha multiplied a widow's small jar of oil to fill all her vessels, saving her from debt.
facts.didYouKnow: The oil stopped flowing only when she ran out of containers.

facts.title: Axe Head Floats
facts.description: Elisha made an iron axe head float on water after it fell into the Jordan River.
facts.didYouKnow: This showed God's care even for everyday problems.

facts.title: Daniel's 70 Weeks
facts.description: Daniel 9 predicted the exact timing of Messiah's coming, 483 years after the decree to rebuild Jerusalem.
facts.didYouKnow: This is one of the most precise prophecies in Scripture.

facts.title: Destruction of Tyre Predicted
facts.description: Ezekiel predicted Tyre would be destroyed and never rebuilt, which happened exactly as foretold.
facts.didYouKnow: Alexander the Great fulfilled this prophecy in 332 BC.

facts.title: Israel's Regathering
facts.description: Multiple prophets predicted Israel would be scattered and regathered, fulfilled in 1948.
facts.didYouKnow: After 2,000 years, Israel became a nation again in one day.

facts.title: Born of David's Line
facts.description: Prophecies required the Messiah to be a descendant of King David, fulfilled through Mary and Joseph.
facts.didYouKnow: Both Matthew and Luke trace Jesus' genealogy to David.

facts.title: Gothic Bible Translation
facts.description: Ulfilas created the Gothic alphabet to translate the Bible in the 4th century.
facts.didYouKnow: This was the first Bible translation for Germanic peoples.

facts.title: Latin Vulgate
facts.description: Jerome's Latin Vulgate (405 AD) was the Catholic Church's official Bible for over 1,000 years.
facts.didYouKnow: Jerome translated directly from Hebrew and Greek, not just Greek.

facts.title: English Bible History
facts.description: Over 900 English Bible translations exist, from Wycliffe (1382) to modern versions.
facts.didYouKnow: The Geneva Bible (1560) was the Pilgrims' Bible at Plymouth.

facts.title: Longest Name in Bible
facts.description: Maher-shalal-hash-baz (Isaiah's son) has the longest name, meaning 'quick to plunder, swift to spoil.'
facts.didYouKnow: This name was itself a prophetic message about Assyria.

facts.title: Shortest Book: 3 John
facts.description: 3 John has only 14 verses and 299 words in Greek, making it the shortest book.
facts.didYouKnow: 2 John is the second shortest with only 13 verses.

facts.title: Only Female Judge
facts.description: Deborah was the only female judge of Israel and led the nation to victory in battle.
facts.didYouKnow: She judged Israel under a palm tree called Deborah's Palm.

facts.title: Melchizedek Mystery
facts.description: Melchizedek appears only twice (Genesis 14, Hebrews 7) but is called a priest forever.
facts.didYouKnow: He had no recorded beginning or end, typifying Christ's eternal priesthood.

facts.title: Urim and Thummim
facts.description: These mysterious objects were used by high priests to determine God's will, but their exact nature is unknown.
facts.didYouKnow: They were kept in the high priest's breastplate.

facts.title: Rahab the Heroine
facts.description: Rahab, a Canaanite prostitute, saved Israelite spies and became part of Jesus' lineage.
facts.didYouKnow: She married Salmon and became the great-great-grandmother of David.

facts.title: Solomon's Wisdom
facts.description: God gave Solomon wisdom beyond all others. He wrote 3,000 proverbs and 1,005 songs.
facts.didYouKnow: People came from all nations to hear Solomon's wisdom.

facts.title: Paul's Conversion
facts.description: Saul of Tarsus persecuted Christians until Jesus appeared to him on the Damascus road.
facts.didYouKnow: He was blind for 3 days until Ananias prayed for him.

facts.title: Jesus Healed the Blind
facts.description: Jesus healed many blind people, including a man blind from birth by putting mud on his eyes.
facts.didYouKnow: The man had to wash in the Pool of Siloam to receive his sight.

facts.title: Healing the Paralytic
facts.description: Four friends lowered a paralyzed man through a roof to Jesus, who forgave his sins and healed him.
facts.didYouKnow: Jesus first forgave sins, then healed to prove he had authority to forgive.

facts.title: Woman with Issue of Blood
facts.description: A woman who bled for 12 years touched Jesus' garment and was instantly healed.
facts.didYouKnow: Jesus felt power leave him when she touched him in faith.

facts.title: Cursing the Fig Tree
facts.description: Jesus cursed a fig tree for not bearing fruit, and it withered immediately.
facts.didYouKnow: This symbolized judgment on Israel for not bearing spiritual fruit.

facts.title: John the Baptist's Message
facts.description: John baptized with water and prepared the way for Jesus, calling people to repent.
facts.didYouKnow: He said he wasn't worthy to untie Jesus' sandals.

facts.title: Nicodemus Visits at Night
facts.description: Nicodemus, a Pharisee, came to Jesus at night and learned about being born again.
facts.didYouKnow: Jesus told him 'You must be born again' (John 3).

facts.title: Woman at the Well
facts.description: Jesus talked with a Samaritan woman and revealed he knew about her five husbands.
facts.didYouKnow: Jews normally didn't speak to Samaritans, especially women.

facts.title: Zacchaeus the Tax Collector
facts.description: Zacchaeus climbed a tree to see Jesus and was transformed, giving back what he stole.
facts.didYouKnow: He promised to give half his possessions to the poor.

facts.title: The Good Samaritan
facts.description: Jesus' parable shows a Samaritan helping a wounded Jew when religious leaders passed by.
facts.didYouKnow: This redefined who our 'neighbor' is.

facts.title: Prodigal Son Returns
facts.description: A rebellious son wasted his inheritance but was welcomed home by his forgiving father.
facts.didYouKnow: This illustrates God's joy when sinners repent.

facts.title: 666 - Number of the Beast
facts.description: Revelation 13:18 identifies 666 as the number of the beast, representing imperfection.
facts.didYouKnow: 777 would be perfect (3x7), so 666 falls short three times.

facts.title: 153 Fish Caught
facts.description: After the resurrection, disciples caught exactly 153 fish when Jesus told them where to cast nets.
facts.didYouKnow: The net didn't break despite this large catch.

facts.title: 144,000 Sealed
facts.description: Revelation mentions 144,000 servants of God sealed from the 12 tribes (12,000 each).
facts.didYouKnow: This represents complete protection of God's people.

facts.title: First Century Christianity
facts.description: Christianity spread rapidly despite persecution, reaching from Jerusalem to Rome within 30 years.
facts.didYouKnow: By 300 AD, about 10% of the Roman Empire was Christian.

facts.title: Emperor Nero's Persecution
facts.description: Nero blamed Christians for Rome's fire in 64 AD and began severe persecutions.
facts.didYouKnow: Peter and Paul were likely martyred during Nero's reign.

facts.title: Constantine's Conversion
facts.description: Emperor Constantine legalized Christianity in 313 AD after seeing a cross in the sky before battle.
facts.didYouKnow: He saw the words 'In this sign, conquer' with the cross.

facts.title: Monks Preserved Scripture
facts.description: Medieval monks hand-copied Bible manuscripts, preserving Scripture for future generations.
facts.didYouKnow: It took about a year to copy one complete Bible by hand.

facts.title: Cyrus Named 150 Years Early
facts.description: Isaiah prophesied Cyrus would decree Jerusalem's rebuilding, 150 years before Cyrus was born.
facts.didYouKnow: Isaiah even named Cyrus specifically in the prophecy.

facts.title: Jesus Born in Bethlehem
facts.description: Micah predicted the Messiah's birthplace 700 years before Jesus was born there.
facts.didYouKnow: Mary and Joseph were only in Bethlehem because of a census.

facts.title: Messiah Rides a Donkey
facts.description: Zechariah prophesied the king would come riding on a donkey, fulfilled on Palm Sunday.
facts.didYouKnow: This showed he came in peace, not war (kings rode horses for war).

facts.title: Acrostic Psalms
facts.description: Several Psalms (like 119) are acrostics, with verses starting with successive Hebrew letters.
facts.didYouKnow: Psalm 119 has 22 sections, one for each Hebrew letter.

facts.title: Book of Job Poetry
facts.description: Most of Job (chapters 3-41) is written in Hebrew poetry, among the oldest in the world.
facts.didYouKnow: Only the prologue and epilogue are in prose.

facts.title: Chiastic Structure
facts.description: Many biblical passages use chiasmus (ABBA pattern) for emphasis and memory.
facts.didYouKnow: The entire Gospel of John is arranged in a giant chiasm.

facts.title: Peshitta Syriac Version
facts.description: The Peshitta is a Syriac Bible translation from the 2nd century, still used by Eastern churches.
facts.didYouKnow: Syriac is a dialect of Aramaic, Jesus' language.

facts.title: Coptic Bible Translation
facts.description: The Bible was translated into Coptic (Egyptian) in the 2nd century for Egyptian Christians.
facts.didYouKnow: These are some of the oldest Bible translations.

facts.title: Barnabas the Encourager
facts.description: Barnabas ('son of encouragement') vouched for Paul when others feared him.
facts.didYouKnow: He sold his land to help the early church.

facts.title: Timothy, Paul's Son in Faith
facts.description: Timothy was mentored by Paul and became a pastor at a young age.
facts.didYouKnow: Paul wrote two letters to him that are in the Bible.

facts.title: Lydia, First European Convert
facts.description: Lydia, a businesswoman from Thyatira, was the first person converted in Europe.
facts.didYouKnow: She sold purple cloth, an expensive luxury item.

facts.title: Priscilla and Aquila
facts.description: This tent-making couple taught Apollos and hosted a church in their home.
facts.didYouKnow: Priscilla is often mentioned first, suggesting she was prominent.

facts.title: Stephen, First Martyr
facts.description: Stephen was stoned to death for his faith, becoming Christianity's first martyr.
facts.didYouKnow: Saul (Paul) watched and approved of his stoning.

facts.title: Philip the Evangelist
facts.description: Philip preached in Samaria and baptized the Ethiopian eunuch.
facts.didYouKnow: He had four daughters who prophesied.

facts.title: Pentecost Tongues of Fire
facts.description: The Holy Spirit descended on 120 believers with tongues of fire and they spoke in other languages.
facts.didYouKnow: People from every nation understood them in their own language.

facts.title: Peter's Shadow Healed
facts.description: People were healed just by Peter's shadow falling on them as he passed by.
facts.didYouKnow: The sick were laid in the streets hoping for this.

facts.title: Paul's Handkerchiefs Healed
facts.description: Handkerchiefs that touched Paul were used to heal the sick and cast out demons.
facts.didYouKnow: This happened during Paul's ministry in Ephesus.

facts.title: Peter Raised Tabitha
facts.description: Peter raised Tabitha (Dorcas) from the dead in Joppa.
facts.didYouKnow: She was known for making clothes for widows.

facts.title: Paul Survived Snake Bite
facts.description: A poisonous snake bit Paul on Malta, but he shook it off and suffered no harm.
facts.didYouKnow: The islanders first thought he was a murderer, then a god.

facts.title: Prison Doors Opened
facts.description: An angel opened prison doors and freed the apostles during the night.
facts.didYouKnow: The guards found the doors locked but the prison empty.

facts.title: Eutychus Fell from Window
facts.description: Eutychus fell from a third-story window during Paul's long sermon and died, but Paul raised him.
facts.didYouKnow: He fell asleep during the sermon and fell out the window.

facts.title: Papyrus Manuscripts
facts.description: Most ancient New Testament manuscripts were written on papyrus, made from reeds.
facts.didYouKnow: Papyrus degrades quickly except in very dry climates like Egypt.

facts.title: Codex Over Scroll
facts.description: Christians pioneered the use of codex (book form) over scrolls in the 2nd century.
facts.didYouKnow: This made it easier to find specific passages quickly.

facts.title: Council of Jerusalem
facts.description: The first church council (Acts 15) decided Gentiles didn't need to become Jews first.
facts.didYouKnow: This was crucial for Christianity spreading beyond Judaism.

facts.title: Scattered Among Nations
facts.description: Deuteronomy predicted Jews would be scattered among all nations, fulfilled multiple times.
facts.didYouKnow: This happened in 586 BC, 70 AD, and 135 AD.

facts.title: Rachel Weeping Prophecy
facts.description: Jeremiah prophesied Rachel weeping for her children, fulfilled in Herod's massacre.
facts.didYouKnow: Herod killed all boys under 2 in Bethlehem trying to kill Jesus.

facts.title: Called Out of Egypt
facts.description: Hosea prophesied 'Out of Egypt I called my son,' fulfilled when Jesus returned from Egypt.
facts.didYouKnow: Joseph and Mary fled to Egypt to escape Herod.

facts.title: Four Gospels, One Story
facts.description: Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John tell Jesus' story from different perspectives.
facts.didYouKnow: Matthew wrote for Jews, Mark for Romans, Luke for Greeks, John for everyone.

facts.title: Gospel Symbols
facts.description: The four Gospels are symbolized by man (Matthew), lion (Mark), ox (Luke), eagle (John).
facts.didYouKnow: These come from Ezekiel's vision of four living creatures.

facts.title: Synoptic Gospels
facts.description: Matthew, Mark, and Luke are called synoptic ('seeing together') because of their similar viewpoints.
facts.didYouKnow: John's Gospel is quite different, focusing on Jesus' divine nature.

facts.title: 10 Plagues of Egypt
facts.description: God sent 10 specific plagues on Egypt: blood, frogs, gnats, flies, livestock disease, boils, hail, locusts, darkness, firstborn death.
facts.didYouKnow: Each plague targeted a specific Egyptian god.

facts.title: 8 People on the Ark
facts.description: Only Noah, his wife, his 3 sons, and their wives (8 people total) survived the flood.
facts.didYouKnow: All people alive today descended from these 8 people.

facts.title: 70 Disciples Sent Out
facts.description: Jesus sent out 70 (or 72) disciples in pairs to preach and heal.
facts.didYouKnow: This represented all the nations of the world (70 nations in Genesis 10).

facts.title: Mary and Martha
facts.description: These sisters were Jesus' friends. Mary sat at Jesus' feet while Martha served.
facts.didYouKnow: Jesus said Mary chose the better part by learning from him.

facts.title: Lazarus, Friend of Jesus
facts.description: Lazarus was raised from the dead after being in the tomb 4 days.
facts.didYouKnow: This miracle convinced many to believe in Jesus.

facts.title: Thomas Doubted
facts.description: Thomas doubted Jesus' resurrection until he saw and touched Jesus' wounds.
facts.didYouKnow: Jesus said 'Blessed are those who haven't seen yet believe.'

facts.title: John, the Beloved
facts.description: John was the disciple whom Jesus loved, the only apostle not martyred.
facts.didYouKnow: He lived to old age and wrote 5 New Testament books.

facts.title: James and John, Sons of Thunder
facts.description: Jesus nicknamed James and John 'Boanerges' (Sons of Thunder) for their fiery personalities.
facts.didYouKnow: They wanted to call fire down on a Samaritan village.

facts.title: Matthew the Tax Collector
facts.description: Matthew left his lucrative tax collecting job immediately when Jesus called him.
facts.didYouKnow: Tax collectors were hated as traitors working for Rome.

facts.title: Simon the Zealot
facts.description: Simon was a Zealot, part of a radical group that wanted to overthrow Rome.
facts.didYouKnow: He was on the opposite side politically from Matthew the tax collector.

facts.title: Judas Iscariot's Betrayal
facts.description: Judas betrayed Jesus for 30 silver coins, then hanged himself in remorse.
facts.didYouKnow: The field bought with the betrayal money was called Field of Blood.

facts.title: Pontius Pilate
facts.description: Pilate was the Roman governor who sentenced Jesus to death despite finding no fault in him.
facts.didYouKnow: He washed his hands symbolically to show he wasn't responsible.

facts.title: Barabbas Released
facts.description: Pilate released Barabbas, a murderer, instead of Jesus at the crowd's demand.
facts.didYouKnow: This illustrates how Christ died in our place.

facts.title: Simon of Cyrene
facts.description: Simon was forced to carry Jesus' cross when Jesus was too weak.
facts.didYouKnow: His sons Alexander and Rufus later became known in the church.

facts.title: Joseph of Arimathea
facts.description: This wealthy secret disciple provided his own tomb for Jesus' burial.
facts.didYouKnow: He was a member of the Sanhedrin who didn't agree with condemning Jesus.

facts.title: Nicodemus Helped Bury Jesus
facts.description: Nicodemus brought 75 pounds of myrrh and aloes for Jesus' burial.
facts.didYouKnow: This was an extremely expensive gift showing great devotion.

facts.title: Caiaphas the High Priest
facts.description: Caiaphas presided over Jesus' illegal trial and pushed for his crucifixion.
facts.didYouKnow: He unknowingly prophesied that Jesus would die for the nation.

facts.title: Annas, Former High Priest
facts.description: Annas was Caiaphas' father-in-law and still wielded great power.
facts.didYouKnow: Jesus was brought to Annas first before the official trial.

facts.title: Darkness at Crucifixion
facts.description: Darkness covered the land from noon to 3 PM when Jesus was crucified.
facts.didYouKnow: This couldn't have been an eclipse, as Passover is at full moon.

facts.title: Temple Curtain Torn
facts.description: The massive temple curtain tore in two from top to bottom when Jesus died.
facts.didYouKnow: This symbolized direct access to God through Christ.

facts.title: Earthquake at Death
facts.description: An earthquake occurred when Jesus died, splitting rocks and opening tombs.
facts.didYouKnow: Saints were raised and appeared to many in Jerusalem.

facts.title: Guards at the Tomb
facts.description: Roman soldiers guarding Jesus' tomb saw an angel and became like dead men from fear.
facts.didYouKnow: They were bribed to say disciples stole the body.

facts.title: Emmaus Road Appearance
facts.description: Jesus walked with two disciples for miles, explaining Scripture, before revealing himself.
facts.didYouKnow: Their hearts burned within them as he taught.

facts.title: Jesus Ascends to Heaven
facts.description: Jesus ascended into heaven in a cloud 40 days after resurrection.
facts.didYouKnow: Angels promised he would return the same way.

facts.title: Apostle Paul's Journeys
facts.description: Paul traveled over 10,000 miles on three missionary journeys throughout the Roman Empire.
facts.didYouKnow: He planted churches in major cities throughout Asia Minor and Greece.

facts.title: Paul Shipwrecked
facts.description: Paul was shipwrecked three times and spent a night and day in the open sea.
facts.didYouKnow: His final shipwreck on Malta is recorded in Acts 27.

facts.title: Paul Beaten Five Times
facts.description: Paul received the 39 lashes (40 minus 1) five times from Jewish authorities.
facts.didYouKnow: He was also beaten with rods three times and stoned once.

facts.title: Paul in Prison
facts.description: Paul wrote Ephesians, Philippians, Colossians, and Philemon while imprisoned in Rome.
facts.didYouKnow: These are called the 'Prison Epistles.'

facts.title: Triumphal Entry Predicted
facts.description: Zechariah predicted the king would come to Jerusalem riding on a donkey, fulfilled on Palm Sunday.
facts.didYouKnow: The crowd waved palm branches and shouted 'Hosanna.'

facts.title: Sold for Silver
facts.description: Zechariah prophesied the Messiah would be valued at 30 pieces of silver.
facts.didYouKnow: This was the price of a slave in that time.

facts.title: Potter's Field Prophecy
facts.description: Zechariah predicted the silver would be thrown to the potter in God's house.
facts.didYouKnow: The priests bought a potter's field with Judas' returned silver.

facts.title: Pierced Hands and Feet
facts.description: Psalm 22 predicted piercing of hands and feet centuries before crucifixion was invented.
facts.didYouKnow: This Psalm also predicted casting lots for his clothing.

facts.title: Gall and Vinegar
facts.description: Psalm 69 predicted they would give the Messiah gall and vinegar to drink.
facts.didYouKnow: This happened while Jesus was on the cross.

facts.title: The Lord's Prayer
facts.description: Jesus taught his disciples a model prayer covering worship, provision, forgiveness, and protection.
facts.didYouKnow: It appears in both Matthew and Luke with slight variations.

facts.title: Beatitudes
facts.description: Jesus began the Sermon on the Mount with 8 blessings, called the Beatitudes.
facts.didYouKnow: They describe the character of citizens of God's kingdom.

facts.title: Great Commission
facts.description: Jesus' final command was to make disciples of all nations, baptizing and teaching them.
facts.didYouKnow: He promised to be with us always, even to the end of the age.

facts.title: Golden Rule
facts.description: Jesus taught 'Do to others what you want them to do to you' (Matthew 7:12).
facts.didYouKnow: This summarizes the Law and the Prophets.

facts.title: Greatest Commandment
facts.description: Jesus said the greatest commands are to love God completely and love your neighbor as yourself.
facts.didYouKnow: All other commands hang on these two.

facts.title: New Commandment
facts.description: Jesus gave a new command: 'Love one another as I have loved you.'
facts.didYouKnow: By this love, everyone would know they were his disciples.

facts.title: Ethiopic Bible
facts.description: Ethiopia has one of the oldest Christian traditions, with Bible translation in the 4th century.
facts.didYouKnow: The Ethiopian eunuch in Acts was an early convert.

facts.title: Armenian Bible
facts.description: Armenia was the first nation to officially adopt Christianity (301 AD) and translated the Bible.
facts.didYouKnow: Their alphabet was created specifically for Bible translation.

facts.title: Bible in Braille
facts.description: The Bible was translated into Braille by Louis Braille himself in the 1800s.
facts.didYouKnow: This made Scripture accessible to the blind worldwide.

facts.title: Sign Language Bibles
facts.description: The Bible has been translated into many sign languages for deaf communities.
facts.didYouKnow: Each sign language is unique, not universal.

facts.title: 500 Witnesses to Resurrection
facts.description: Paul records that Jesus appeared to over 500 people at once after his resurrection.
facts.didYouKnow: Most were still alive when Paul wrote this (1 Corinthians 15:6).

facts.title: 3,000 Saved at Pentecost
facts.description: About 3,000 people were baptized and added to the church on the day of Pentecost.
facts.didYouKnow: This was after Peter's first sermon filled with the Holy Spirit.

facts.title: 5,000 Men Believed
facts.description: After healing the lame beggar, about 5,000 men believed (Acts 4:4).
facts.didYouKnow: This doesn't count women and children, so total was much higher.

facts.title: Ananias and Sapphira
facts.description: This couple lied to the Holy Spirit about their giving and both dropped dead.
facts.didYouKnow: Great fear came upon the whole church after this.

facts.title: Cornelius, First Gentile Convert
facts.description: Cornelius, a Roman centurion, and his household were the first Gentiles to receive the Holy Spirit.
facts.didYouKnow: Peter saw a vision of unclean animals before meeting him.

facts.title: Gamaliel's Wise Counsel
facts.description: Gamaliel, a respected Pharisee, advised not to fight against God by persecuting Christians.
facts.didYouKnow: He was Paul's teacher before Paul's conversion.

facts.title: Agabus Prophesied Famine
facts.description: Agabus accurately prophesied a great famine coming to the Roman world.
facts.didYouKnow: He later prophesied Paul's imprisonment in Jerusalem.

facts.title: Herod Agrippa Struck Down
facts.description: King Herod Agrippa was eaten by worms and died for accepting worship as a god.
facts.didYouKnow: He had just killed James the apostle before this.

facts.title: Aquila and Priscilla Risked Lives
facts.description: This couple risked their lives for Paul, and all Gentile churches were grateful.
facts.didYouKnow: They corrected Apollos' incomplete understanding of Jesus.

facts.title: Onesimus the Slave
facts.description: Onesimus ran away from Philemon but was converted and sent back as a brother.
facts.didYouKnow: Paul wrote Philemon's letter asking him to receive Onesimus back.
